176.source:
function pageuibasics$1Markdown(state) { return "`doit:\"x\" this.close()`\n
\n\ `link:\"back\"back`\n\ `link:\"next\"next`\n\
\n\ \n\
UI â€“ Windows
\n\ \n\ The main tools you will interact with in this environment are windows, menus, and filterable lists.\n\ \n\ Windows are compound objects that usually encapsulate one tool. They can be `hover-video:\"collapsed and expanded\" 'cloxp/videos/win-col-expand', pt(300, 157)`, `hover-video:\"dragged around\" 'cloxp/videos/win-drag', pt(300, 157)`, `hover-video:\"resized\" 'cloxp/videos/win-resize', pt(300, 157)`, and `hover-video:\"aligned\" 'cloxp/videos/win-align', pt(300, 157)`.\n\ \n\ One window at a time can be active. An active window receives keyboard events and delegates those to some object inside it. Often you work with multiple windows / tools at once. To quickly switch between them `hover-video:\"you can use a keyboard shortcut\" 'cloxp/videos/window-nav', pt(500, 257)` `alt-` ` (that is alt-backtick)."; }

179.source:
function pageuibasics$2Markdown(state) { return "`doit:\"x\" this.close()`\n
\n\ `link:\"back\"back`\n\ `link:\"next\"next`\n\
\n\ \n\
UI â€“ Menus
\n\ \n\ Menus provide access to actions in a certain context.\n\ \n\ - __`hover-video:\"Main menu\" 'cloxp/videos/world-menu', pt(400, 247)`:__ When you right click (on MacOS also Ctrl-click) into the white background, the main menu appears. It's items allow you to open the most important tools.\n\ \n\ - __`hover-video:\"Code editor menu\" 'cloxp/videos/codeeditor-menu', pt(330, 170)`:__ Actions to browse, modify, evaluate code objects are included here. You also get access to settings such as shortcut bindings.\n\ \n\ - __`hover-video:\"System browser menu\" 'cloxp/videos/browser-menu', pt(500, 400)`:__ Actions related to general browser behavior and selected items.\n\ \n\ Other objects may provide additional actions and menus.\n\ "; }

182.source:
function pageuibasics$3Markdown(state) { return "`doit:\"x\" this.close()`\n
\n\ `link:\"back\"back`\n\ `doit:\"next\"`\n\
\n\ \n\
UI â€“ Selection lists
\n\ \n\ One repeating pattern when interacting with cloxp is the selection of items. Be it for switching windows, code completion, or selecting a search result, often a large list of options need to be searched and one selected.\n\ \n\ Cloxp provides selection narrowers for this task. A narrower is a screen-sized list with an input element at the bottom. You can filter content by typing substrings into it. You usually can enter multiple, space separated substrings to filter all items containing *both* terms.\n\ \n\ `doit:\"Click here\" this.wrappedVideoMorph('cloxp/videos/sys-browser-narrow', true, this.getExtent());` to see how to search for all clojure symbols in namespaces ending with core and containing the string map.\n\ \n\ When the System Browse is active you can use `alt-shift-t` to search for symbols."; }

191.source:
function pagehelpoverview$0Markdown(state) { return "`doit:\"x\" this.close()`\n\
\n\ `link:\"back\"'start', 0 `\n\ `doit:\"next\"`\n\
\n\ \n\
Help â€“ Topics
\n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\
__UI basics:__\n\
    \n\
  • `link:\"windows\"'uibasics',1`
    • \n\
  • `link:\"menus\"'uibasics',2`
    • \n\
  • `link:\"selection lists\"'uibasics',3`
    • \n\
\n\ 		__Clojure tools:__\n\
    \n\
  • `link:\"workspace\"'clojuretools',1`
    • \n\
  • `link:\"system browser\"'clojuretools',2`
    • \n\
  • `link:\"clojars browser\"'clojuretools',3`
    • \n\
\n\
__Writing Clojure code:__\n\ \n\
    \n\
  • `link:\"evaluation\"'clojure_coding',1`
    • \n\
  • `link:\"print-inspection\"'clojure_coding',2`
    • \n\
  • `link:\"completions\"'clojure_coding',3`
    • \n\
  • `link:\"paredit\"'paredit',1`
    • \n\
\n\ 		__File and operating system tools__\n\
    \n\
  • `link:\"Files and directories\"'ostools',1`
    • \n\
  • `link:\"Searching\"'ostools',2`
    • \n\
  • `link:\"Running shell processes\"'ostools',3`
    • \n\
\n\
\n\ \n\ "; }

200.source:
function pageclojuretools$1Markdown(state) { return "`doit:\"x\" this.close()`\n
\n\ `link:\"back\"back`\n\ `link:\"next\"next`\n\
\n\ \n\
Clojure Tools â€“ Workspace
\n\ \n\ Workspaces are code editors that allow you to enter and evaluate Clojure code. They are useful if you need a \"scratch\" space, for example, to try out code snippets or to inspect objects. `doit:\"Give me a demo!\" this.wrappedVideoMorph('cloxp/videos/cloxp-eval', true, this.getExtent());`\n\ \n\ To evaluate an expression, either select it entirely or move the cursor behind it. Then press `alt-enter`. The evaluation result will appear in a box at the bottom. you can then either insert the evaluation result in the workspace, open another workspace with it, or just continue working. `doit:\"Show me\"`.\n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ Unless specifically set via a `ns` or `in-ns` form, workspaces will evaluate code in the _user_ namespace."; }

209.source:
function pageparedit$1Markdown(state) { return "
`doit:\"x\" this.close()`
\n\
\n\ `link:\"back\"back`\n\ `doit:\"next\"`\n\
\n\ \n\
Paredit
\n\ \n\ By default, clojure text editors have _paredit_ enabled. Paredit uses an AST behind the scene to allow structural editing operations. If you don't want it, you can disable paredit anytime via the `hover-video:\"context menu of editors\" 'cloxp/videos/paredit-disable', pt(450,260)`.\n\ \n\ action | shortcut | what it does\n\ -----|--------|-----------\n\ open list | `(` and `[` and `{` | `aâ«¿aaâ‡’a(â«¿)aa`\n\ close list | `)` and `]` and `}` | `(aâ«¿aa)â‡’(aaa)â«¿`\n\ wrap around | `alt-(` and `alt-[` and `alt-{` | `aâ«¿aaâ‡’a(â«¿aa)`\n\ \"slurp\" | `ctrl-shift-(` and `ctrl-shift-)` | `a (bb â«¿cc)â‡’(a bb â«¿cc)` and `(bb â«¿cc) aaâ‡’(bb â«¿cc aa)`\n\ \"barf\" | `ctrl-shift-]` and `ctrl-shift-[` | `(a bb â«¿cc)â‡’a (bb â«¿cc)` and `(bb â«¿cc aa)â‡’(bb â«¿cc) aa`\n\ delete | `backspace` and `delete` and `ctrl-d` | Based on where they will be invoked will delete expressions, chars or nothing\n\ delete expression | `ctrl-alt-k` and `ctrl-alt-backspace` | `a â«¿bb cccâ‡’a â«¿ ccc`\n\ splice | `alt-s` | `(a â«¿bb)â‡’a â«¿bb`\n\ splice delete | `alt-shift-up` and `alt-shift-down` | `(a â«¿bb)â‡’â«¿bb` and `(a â«¿bb)â‡’aâ«¿`\n\ split | `alt-shift-s` | `(a â«¿bb)â‡’(a) â«¿(bb)`\n\ transpose | `ctrl-alt-t` | `(a â«¿bb)â‡’(bb â«¿a)`\n\ indent | `tab` | Indents line or selection.\n\ newline | `enter` | Inserts newline and indents.\n\ "; }

212.source:
function pagestart$0Markdown(state) { return "\n\ \n\
![](/core/media/cloxp-logo.png)
\n\ \n\
You just entered *cloxp*
A Clojure IDE for live and interactive development
\n\ \n\
\n\ \n\
\n\
    \n\
  • `doit:\"Getting started\" var ctrl = $morph(/ClojureController/); var t = ctrl.bounds().top(); var newB = ctrl.bounds().translatedBy(pt(-100,50-t)); var helper = this; helper.withCSSTransitionForAllMorphsDo([helper, ctrl], function() { ctrl.setPosition(newB.topLeft()); helper.align(helper.bounds().topCenter(), newB.bottomCenter()); }, 1000, function() { helper.showPage('getstarted',1); });`
    • \n\
  • `doit:\"Help overview\" this.showPage('helpoverview',0);`
    • \n\
  • `doit:\"Close\" this.close();`
    • \n\
\n\
\n\ \n\
\n\ \n\ \n\
\n\
\n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ \n\ "; }

218.source:
function pageclojure_coding$1Markdown(state) { return "`doit:\"x\" this.close()`\n
\n\ `link:\"back\"back`\n\ `link:\"next\"'clojure_coding', 2`\n\
\n\ \n\
Evaluating Clojure code
\n\ \n\ All code editors showing Clojure code can evaluate expressions. This includes workspaces, code views in the System Browser, and text editors presenting clj files. Evaluation can be triggered via the context menu or key shortcuts. When evaluating code it matters _what is selected and where the cursor is placed_. If a selection exists, the code inside the selection is evaluated. Otherwise the evaluation target is the last expression to the left of the cursor.\n\ \n\ Additionally, when you modify top-level code such as function definitions, you can directly evaluate the entire top-level expression.\n\ \n\ Evaluation results (and errors) appear in a box at the bottom. If you want to use the evaluation result you can insert it into the current editor or open it in another.\n\ \n\ `Alt-Enter`: Evaluate selection or last expression.\n\ \n\ `Alt-Shift-Space`: Evaluate top-level expression.\n\ \n\ `Alt-Shift-Enter`: Insert eval result (or `link:\"inspect\"'clojure_coding', 2` when no result present).\n\ \n\ `Alt-o`: Open eval result in a new window.\n\ \n\ `doit:\"Give me a demo!\" this.wrappedVideoMorph('cloxp/videos/cloxp-eval', true, this.getExtent());`\n\ \n\ "; }

221.source:
function pageclojure_coding$2Markdown(state) { return "`doit:\"x\" this.close()`\n
\n\ `link:\"back\"back`\n\ `link:\"next\"'clojure_coding', 3`\n\
\n\ \n\
Print-Inspecting Clojure objects
\n\ \n\ Apart from normal evaluation that produces a simple `str` representation of the resulting object you can also pretty print (\"print inspect\") results.\n\ \n\ `Alt-Shift-Enter`: Print inspect.\n\ \n\ By default, a print depth of 6 will be used. You can determine the print depth by giving a count argument to the print inspect command. You do this by pressing `Ctrl-number` before the print inspect command. For example to print to depth 15 you would press `Ctrl-1 Ctrl-5 Alt-Shift-Enter`.\n\ \n\ When a result box is present you can press `Alt-Shift-Enter` again to insert it's text into the editor. Press `Alt-o` to open it in another editor.\n\ "; }

224.source:
function pageclojure_coding$3Markdown(state) { return "`doit:\"x\" this.close()`\n
\n\ `link:\"back\"back`\n\ `link:\"next\"'paredit', 1`\n\
\n\ \n\
Code completions
\n\ \n\ Cloxp provides context specific static and dynamic code completions. You can eiter invoke completions via the context menu or with:\n\ \n\ `Alt-Shift-p`: List completions.\n\ \n\ Here is how you work with it:\n\ \n\ - `hover-video:\"Completing functions\" 'cloxp/videos/compl-menu', pt(500, 278)`\n\ - `hover-video:\"Completing namespaces and namespace functions\" 'cloxp/videos/compl-shortcut', pt(500, 278)`\n\ - `hover-video:\"Property completion\" 'cloxp/videos/compl-properties', pt(520, 290)` (dynamic, requires eval, great to \"browse\" through object interfaces)"; }

227.source:
function pagegetstarted$1Markdown(state) { return "`doit:\"x\" this.close()`\n\
\n\ `link:\"back\"back`\n\ `doit:\"next\"`\n\
\n\ \n\
Getting Started
\n\ \n\ The `doit:\"clojure controller\" showMarkerFor($morph(/ClojureController/))` indicates the connection state to Clojure repl servers, allows you to switch connections, and has buttons to open Clojure tools. If the connection bar indicates that no connection exists, click the `doit:\"start button\" showMarkerFor($morph(/startReplServerButton/))`.\n\ \n\ Once the server is started (you can close its console view), open a `doit:\"Cojure workspace\" showMarkerFor($morph(/openClojureWorkspace/))`. In it you can `doit:\"evaluate code\" this.wrappedVideoMorph('cloxp/videos/cloxp-eval', true, this.getExtent());`. In case you are unfamiliar with _paredit_ you probably want to `link:\"read this\"'paredit',1`.\n\ \n\ To browse the namespaces and functions of the Clojure runtime system, open a `doit:\"System Browser\" showMarkerFor($morph(/openClojureBrowser/))`. It allows to see the loaded namespaces, modify them and their definitions, and create new namespaces.\n\ \n\ To learn more about the other tools and workflows, head over to the `link:\"help overview\"'helpoverview',0`."; }
